explanation:
pathetic, inflammatory


The description "pathetic, inflammatory" reflects an opinion and not objective fact. These kinds of words can influence how readers feel before they have a chance to make up their own minds. Removing them would make the statement more neutral and allow people to judge the situation based on the information itself. Readers can still reach their own conclusions without being guided by emotionally charged language.

bizarrely claimed


The adjective "bizarrely" represents a subjective assessment rather than objective fact. Rather than address any points, it dismisses them without explanation.


The word, 'claimed' had a hyperlink to a post on X by @RapidResponse47:


WALZ: "There is no verifiable evidence that any of this is making America safer."@DHSgov @ICEgov has prevented countless murders, rapes, and assaults of American citizens by getting criminal illegals off our streets.

What does this sick freak find offensive about that? pic.twitter.com/qF0H5lVCIL

— Rapid Response 47 (@RapidResponse47) January 8, 2026

Barring the emotionally charged (or, as one could say, "inflammatory") language and the ad hominem attack (attacking Walz as a person rather than addressing his claims with evidence), the full crime statistics for 2025 are not available as of January 10, 2026. Based on data obtained from the Real-Time Crime Index, there has been a downward trend for murders, rapes, and assaults nationwide. Since the data for November and December are not available, I used data from January-October for each year to create the following:


Examining the percentage change shows that it has remained negative over the past several years, with a larger decline occurring between 2024 and 2025. However, it is difficult to determine whether this change can be attributed specifically to President Trump's immigration enforcement policies or to other contributing factors.


References:

Real-Time Crime Index, Full Sample, Nationwide's composite agencies. (2024). final_sample [Data set]. AH Datalytics. https://realtimecrimeindex.com

‚Äúthere is no verifiable evidence‚Äù that President Donald J. Trump‚Äôs immigration enforcement operations are ‚Äúmaking America safer.‚Äù


Similarly to the previous comment, there was a downwards trend in crime over a couple years, so it is hard to correlate the trend solely to President Trump's immigrant enforcement operations.


References:

Real-Time Crime Index, Full Sample, Nationwide's composite agencies. (2024). final_sample [Data set]. AH Datalytics. https://realtimecrimeindex.com

Radical Left lunatics


This description relies on emotionally charged language rather than objective analysis. Terms such as "Radical Left" and "lunatic" are often used in political rhetoric to shape perception and can carry negative connotations (Oxford University Press, n.d.) that discredit the subject rather than explain their views.


Governor Tim Walz's political positions are more accurately described as center-left by international standards and progressive-left within the U.S. context. As governor, he has supported policies such as expanded labor protections, universal school meals, gun safety measures, protections for abortion rights and LGBTQ+ individuals, and investments in clean energy (Vote Smart | Facts For All, 2024). These positions place him left of center in U.S. politics.


Economically, Walz supports government involvement to reduce inequality, increased public spending on social services, and progressive taxation, aligning with social-democratic or progressive liberal approaches (Vote Smart | Facts For All, 2024). While he began his career as a more moderate Democrat, his positions have shifted left over time. He continues to work within existing democratic institutions, making descriptions of him as "far-left" or "extreme" more rhetorical than analytical.


References:

Masters, C. (2024, August 9). How Tim Walz went from ‚ÄúBlue Dog Democrat‚Äù to progressive champion. NPR. https://www.npr.org/2024/08/09/nx-s1-5068291/tim-walz-kamala-harris-vice-president-2024-trump-minnesota

Oxford University Press. (n.d.). Lunatic, adj., 1.c. In Oxford English dictionary. Retrieved January 9, 2026, from https://doi.org/10.1093/OED/8714103457 https://justfacts.votesmart.org/candidate/biography/65443/tim-walz

Vote Smart | Facts For All. (2024). Vote Smart. https://justfacts.votesmart.org/candidate/evaluations/65443/tim-walz

blinded by their deep delusions and seething hatred


The phrase "blinded by their deep delusions and seething hatred" uses strong emotional language rather than factual statements. It assumes the thoughts and motives of others without evidence and is meant to influence how readers feel about them. This type of wording does not support objective discussion and shifts attention away from facts or specific actions.

untethered from reality


The phrase "untethered from reality" dismisses opposing views without directly addressing or responding to the arguments being made. Rather than offering evidence or counterpoints, it labels the position in a way that avoids substantive discussion.

indisputable evidence


This wording presents a strong claim without providing sources or supporting data. Without clear evidence, the claim cannot be independently verified and should be treated as an assertion rather than a confirmed fact.

literally saving lives


The phrase uses exaggerated language to emphasize impact. Even if immigration enforcement had some effect, describing it in absolute terms overstates what can be reliably demonstrated. Without clear evidence directly linking the policies to specific outcomes, this wording functions as rhetorical emphasis rather than a precise or verifiable claim.

largest ever


Based on homicide data from the CDE, 2025 shows the largest year-to-year decline in homicides since at least 1985 (Federal Bureau of Investigation, 2023). Although data for December 2025 is incomplete, the missing information is unlikely to significantly alter the overall trend.


In the article, the word "saw" links to an Axios article that reports percentage changes between 2024 and 2025 and places the decline in a broader context. The article notes that the reduction in homicides is part of a wider decrease in violent crime following the increase observed during the COVID period (Bragg, 2025).


References:

Bragg, J. (2025, December 24). U.S. murders on pace for largest one-year drop on record. Axios. https://www.axios.com/2025/12/24/us-trump-murder-data-killing-crime-national-guard

Federal Bureau of Investigation. (2023). Federal Bureau of Investigation Crime Data Explorer. Cjis.gov. https://cde.ucr.cjis.gov/LATEST/webapp/#/pages/explorer/crime/shr.

especially steep drops


The phrase implies a direct connection between enforcement actions and reductions in crime. While a correlation is suggested, additional evidence is needed to establish causation. Other factors, such as local government programs and long-term crime trends, could also contribute to these declines.


The word "undertook" links to a Heritage Foundation article highlighting crime reductions in Washington, D.C., but the article does not provide the full context. Data from 2023-2024 shows an even larger percentage decrease in overall violent crime and every sub-category save for burglary, suggesting that the trend was already downward before these enforcement actions (District Crime Data at a Glance | Mpdc, 2026). Additionally, data for December 2025 is incomplete, so the full-year impact is not fully captured.


The word "cities" links to an ABC News article reporting mid-November 2025 figures, noting large percentage drops in specific crimes such as homicides, robberies, and carjackings (Minock, 2025). When the full-year data is examined, the decreases are smaller and closely match trends from previous years. For example, homicides decreased by 32% in 2025, similar to a 31% decrease in 2024. Robberies were down 37% in 2025, which is similar to 39% in 2024. Carjackings showed a similar pattern with being down 50% in 2025 and 48% in 2024 (Carjacking | Mpdc, n.d.; DC Crime Data and Stats - Robbery, 2024; U.S. ATTORNEY‚ÄôS OFFICE FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, 2024). These figures indicate that the observed reductions may not be solely attributable to federal immigration enforcement.

The phrase "steep drop" links to another ABC article noting the largest year-to-year decline since 1985 (Hutchinson, 2025). While 2025 does show a significant drop in homicides based on CDE data, the overall downward trend across multiple years suggests that these declines are part of an ongoing pattern rather than the result of a single policy (Federal Bureau of Investigation, 2023). In addition, the data from areas like Chicago and D.C. have maintained a downwards trend without exhibiting a 'steep drop' (Chicago, n.d.; District Crime Data at a Glance | Mpdc, 2026).

References:

Carjacking | mpdc. (n.d.). Mpdc.dc.gov. https://mpdc.dc.gov/page/carjacking

Chicago. (n.d.). Violence and Victimization Trends. www.chicago.gov. https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/sites/vrd/home/violence-victimization.html

DC Crime Data and Stats - Robbery. (2024). Crimedatadc.com. https://www.crimedatadc.com/todate/robbery

District Crime Data at a Glance | mpdc. (2026, January 9). Mpdc.dc.gov. https://mpdc.dc.gov/dailycrime

Federal Bureau of Investigation. (2023). Federal Bureau of Investigation Crime Data Explorer. Cjis.gov. https://cde.ucr.cjis.gov/LATEST/webapp/#/pages/explorer/crime/shr.

Hutchinson, B. (2025, December 31). US poised to end 2025 with the largest one-year drop in homicides ever recorded: Experts. ABC News.https://abcnews.go.com/US/us-poised-end-2025-largest-year-drop-homicides/story?id=128646976

Minock, N. (2025, November 14). US Marshals Service Director says DC safer after President Trump‚Äôs crime crackdown. WJLA. https://wjla.com/news/local/us-marshals-service-director-claims-dc-safer-after-president-trumps-crime-crackdown-washington-capital-carjackings-gadyaces-serralta-cashless-bail-mpd-police-union-congress

Stimson, C. (2019). Trump‚Äôs D.C. Crime Success Puts Spotlight on Chicago‚Äôs Deadly ‚ÄúWar Zone.‚Äù The Heritage Foundation. https://www.heritage.org/crime-and-justice/commentary/trumps-dc-crime-success-puts-spotlight-chicagos-deadly-war-zone

U.S. ATTORNEY‚ÄôS OFFICE FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. (2024). 2024 Violent Crime Outcomes. In justice.gov (p. 2). https://www.justice.gov/usao-dc/media/1382896/dl?inline

150 illegal alien sex offenders


The term 'illegal alien' dehumanizes and oversimplifies various complex situations individuals may be in.


The operation referred to as Operation Dirtbag (Leonard, 2026) resulted in the arrest of 230 undocumented immigrants. According to ICE Deputy Director Madison Sheahan, those arrested included 54 individuals identified as sexual predators, 164 charged with sexual offenses, two convicted murderers, one convicted drug trafficker, and eight others charged with serious felonies such as aggravated battery, possession of narcotics, possession of marijuana, possession of a controlled substance, and burglary (Cabrera, 2025; Leonard, 2026).


While this data describes the arrests and the criminal histories of those individuals, it does not provide evidence of an impact on overall crime rates.


References:

Cabrera, S. (2025, November 13). ICE lauds Florida operation netting 230 arrests, sends out warning to Venezuelans who lost TPS. WLRN. https://www.wlrn.org/immigration/2025-11-13/ice-immigration-operation-venezuelans

Leonard, K. (2026). POLITICO Pro: Florida, ICE announce 230 arrests in ‚ÄúOperation Dirtbag.‚Äù. https://subscriber.politicopro.com/article/2025/11/florida-ice-announce-230-arrests-in-operation-dirtbag-00650226

dramatic decrease in violent crime


Violent crime in Chicago has decreased in recent years, with 2025 recording the lowest total violent crime since 2022 (Chicago, n.d.). While this trend is notable, it is not possible to determine whether the decline is the result of immigration enforcement efforts or other factors, such as local policing strategies, community programs, or broader social and economic conditions. The data show a reduction in crime, but causation cannot be inferred from these numbers alone.


References:

Chicago. (n.d.). Violence and Victimization Trends. www.chicago.gov. https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/sites/vrd/home/violence-victimization.html

staggering 70% of the 650,000+ illegal aliens


The word 'staggering' is a subjective intensifier. The claim should be interpreted cautiously, as it is unclear whether the statistic includes minor offenses or how broadly "crime" is defined. Even if accurate, this figure does not necessarily indicate an overall improvement in public safety.


The phrase "650,000 illegal aliens" was linked to a video of Secretary Kristi Noem:


linked to post on x:

NEW: @Sec_Noem announces that 2.6 million illegals have left our country since President Trump took office ‚Äî including 650,000 who were arrested, detained, and deported, and two million who self-deported. pic.twitter.com/8Y5xzsb2KQ

— Rapid Response 47 (@RapidResponse47) January 8, 2026

The figure of 650,000+ was linked to the statement by Secretary Kristi Noem. I struggled finding statistical data supporting the statement, for comparison, The Guardian's ICE tracker reports a total of 352,380 deportations, which is lower than the 650,000 figure often cited (Craft & Witherspoon, 2025; U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, 2025). However, public records show that ICE informed Congress in summer 2024 of a list of 650,000 immigrants with criminal histories whom they planned to locate. The most common offenses included traffic violations (such as drunk driving), immigration violations (such as illegal reentry), and assault (Miroff, 2025). Other sources note that some deported individuals had criminal histories, but nearly 73% of deportations involved people without a criminal conviction (Bier, 2025).


The word "crimes" was linked to a DHS article that highlighted some immigrants captured by ICE with a criminal history; however, it fails to mention other American citizens accidentally arrested as well (Department of Homeland Security, 2025; Sprecher, 2025).


Overall, the statistic may exaggerate the impact of deportations on public safety and should be interpreted in the context of broader ICE enforcement data and definitions of crime.


References:

Bier, D. J. (2025). 5% of People Detained By ICE Have Violent Convictions, 73% No Convictions. Cato.org. https://www.cato.org/blog/5-ice-detainees-have-violent-convictions-73-no-convictions

Craft, W., & Witherspoon, A. (2025, August 29). By the numbers: the latest Ice and CBP data on arrests, detentions and deportations in the US. The Guardian; The Guardian. https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2025/aug/29/trump-immigration-ice-cbp-data

Department of Homeland Security. (2025). ICE Arrests Worst of Worst Criminal Illegal Aliens Including Pedophiles, Rapists and Violent Assailants | Homeland Security. U.S. Department of Homeland Security. https://www.dhs.gov/news/2025/12/17/ice-arrests-worst-worst-criminal-illegal-aliens-including-pedophiles-rapists-and#:~:text=‚ÄúICE%20law%20enforcement,just%20the%20beginning.‚Äù

Miroff, N. (2025, March 11). ICE Isn‚Äôt Delivering the Mass Deportation Trump Wants. The Atlantic. https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2025/03/trump-immigration-deportation-agenda/682005/

Sprecher, A. M. (2025). All the U.S. Citizens Who‚Äôve Been Caught Up in Trump‚Äôs Immigration Crackdown. Nymag.com. https://www.congress.gov/119/meeting/house/118180/documents/HMKP-119-JU00-20250430-SD003.pdf

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. (2025). Detention Management. Www.ice.gov. https://www.ice.gov/detain/detention-management

dropped by nearly 25%


The number is accurate as 111 on-duty law enforcement officers were killed in 2025, compared to 148 in 2024 (Lauer, 2026). While this reflects a decrease in fatalities, it does not account for the number of officers who were injured or shot at while on duty. Data from the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund show a slight increase in the number of officers shot while on duty, rising from 342 in 2024 to 347 in 2025 (National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund, 2026)


Without additional context or evidence establishing causation, presenting this decline in fatalities as a direct result of immigration enforcement risks overstating the relationship. The data demonstrate a change in outcomes but do not, on their own, support a clear cause-and-effect conclusion.


References:

Lauer, C. (2026, January 6). New report shows a 25% drop in deaths of on-duty law enforcement officers. ABC News. https://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/new-report-shows-25-drop-deaths-duty-law-128939135

National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund. (2026). 2025 End-Of-Year Law Enforcement Officers Fatalities Report. In nleomf.org. https://nleomf.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/2025-EOY-Fatality-Report-RGB_FINAL.pdf

Traffic fatalities have dropped dramatically


The linked article covers only the first six months of 2025 and reports an 8.2% decrease in traffic fatalities compared to the same period the previous year (NHTSA, 2025). While this represents the largest mid-year decline observed since 2013, the data is partial and does not reflect the full year.


The total number of traffic fatalities reported is the lowest since 2020, but these figures alone do not establish the cause of the decline or support conclusions about specific policy impacts (NHTSA, 2025).


References:

NHTSA. (2025, September). NHTSA.https://www.nhtsa.gov/press-releases/nhtsa-reports-sharp-drop-traffic-fatalities-first-half-2025

eased congestion in high-immigration cities


The linked article primarily focuses on Los Angeles, which experienced a 1% decrease in traffic delays from 2024 to 2025 (Castleman, 2025). However, it does not include data from other major cities, some of which saw increases during the same period. For example, Chicago and Philadelphia recorded increases in delays of 12% and 31%, respectively (INRIX, 2022). Official data also show increases in cities such as Dallas (7%), Washington, D.C. (13%), and Boston (5%) (INRIX, 2022). Among the cities listed early in the rankings (organized by impact rank), only Los Angeles (-1%) and North Charleston, South Carolina (-3%) showed decreases (INRIX, 2022).


Larger percentage changes appear in smaller cities, with some locations like Greenville (NC), Rochester (NY), and Tallahasee (FL) experiencing increases of up to 100%, while others saw significant declines (INRIX, 2022). For example, Butte, Montana recorded a 67% decrease in delays (INRIX, 2022). However, Butte has a relatively small foreign-born population, approximately 1.4-1.45%, which makes it unlikely that immigration levels alone explain the change (Census Reporter, 2023).


The article also notes that reductions in traffic delays may be influenced by factors such as the continued use of remote work, suggesting that changes in congestion and traffic safety are shaped by multiple variables (Castleman, 2025). As a result, attributing decreased congestion primarily to immigration enforcement or the removal of specific groups of drivers is not clearly supported by the available data.


The word 'congestion' was linked to a post on X by the DHS:


You‚Äôre welcome. https://t.co/exofytTy8E

— Homeland Security (@DHSgov) November 19, 2025

Congestion can vary by time of day and the report mentioned above noted Charlotte to have a 17% increased congestion change from 2024 (INRIX, 2022).


References:

Castleman, T. (2025, December 11). L.A. traffic is getting better. That‚Äôs not entirely a good thing. Los Angeles Times. https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2025-12-11/la-traffic-is-getting-better-thats-not-entirely-good-thing

INRIX. (2022). Global Traffic Scorecard. Inrix. https://inrix.com/scorecard/#city-ranking-list

Census Reporter. (2023). Census Reporter. https://censusreporter.org/profiles/17000US3011390-butte-silver-bow-mt/

more than 9,500 non-English-speaking commercial truck drivers


The reference to ‚Äúnon-English-speaking‚Äù commercial truck drivers introduces a potentially biased framing that emphasizes language ability without clear evidence that it is directly related to roadway safety. The statement suggests a causal link between the removal of these drivers and improvements in traffic safety or congestion, but does not provide supporting data to substantiate that connection. As presented, the phrasing risks implying causation where only correlation, or no demonstrated relationship, has been established.


The word 'removal' is linked to a post on X by Secretary Sean Duffy:

We‚Äôve now knocked 9,500 truck drivers out of service for failing to speak our national language ‚Äî ENGLISH!

This administration will always put you and your family‚Äôs safety first.üöö https://t.co/mRVsMI26Ir

— Secretary Sean Duffy (@SecDuffy) December 10, 2025

English because the national language earlier in the year through Executive Order on March 1, 2025 (The White House, 2025).


References:

The White House. (2025, March 1). Designating English as the Official Language of The United States. The White House. https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/designating-english-as-the-official-language-of-the-united-states/

safety risks on our roadways


Claims about ‚Äúsafety risks on our roadways‚Äù should be considered in light of broader traffic safety data. According to a study by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), the largest share of traffic fatalities is consistently associated with drivers and passenger vehicle occupants (NHTSA, 2025). Fatalities involving pedalcyclists and large trucks remain among the smallest categories in both 2024 and 2025, which may partly reflect the lower number of cyclists and commercial trucks compared to passenger vehicles.


Additionally, national data show that traffic fatalities have been declining for 13 consecutive quarters (Staff, 2025). This ongoing downward trend suggests that changes in roadway safety are influenced by multiple factors over time. As a result, attributing safety improvements primarily to the removal of specific groups or enforcement actions is not clearly supported by the available evidence.


References:

National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. (2025). Traffic Safety Facts Crash Stats: Early Estimates of Motor Vehicle Traffic Fatalities and Fatality Rate by Sub-Categories For the First Half (January-June) of 2025. ROSA P. https://rosap.ntl.bts.gov/view/dot/87710

Staff, C. (2025, September 24). Traffic fatalities trending down in 2025: NHTSA. Commercial Carrier Journal. https://www.ccjdigital.com/regulations/article/15767741/traffic-fatalities-trending-down-in-2025-nhtsa

slashed in half


The claim that fentanyl trafficking has been ‚Äúslashed in half‚Äù lacks clarity and supporting evidence. The phrase is vague and does not specify what is being measured, such as seizures, drug purity, arrests, or estimated trafficking volume. Additionally, the relationship between border enforcement, fentanyl purity, and overdose deaths is complex and influenced by multiple factors. Without clearly defined metrics and data, the claim appears exaggerated and does not establish a direct causal link between border operations and changes in fentanyl-related outcomes.

lower fentanyl purity levels


The DHS article referenced in support of the claim does not mention changes in fentanyl purity level (DHS, 2025). A separate Washington Post article linked in relation to overdose deaths does note a decline in fentanyl purity, which aligns with the initial decrease in overdose deaths observed in 2023 (Ovalle & Cadell, 2026). However, the sources cited do not clearly establish a direct connection between specific enforcement actions and changes in fentanyl purity levels, and the claim is not consistently supported by the referenced materials.


References:

DHS. (2025). Under President Trump and Secretary Noem, the Department of Homeland Security Has Historic Year | Homeland Security. U.S. Department of Homeland Security. https://www.dhs.gov/news/2025/12/19/under-president-trump-and-secretary-noem-department-homeland-security-has-historic

Ovalle, D., & Cadell, C. (2026, January 8). A study offers a surprising reason for plunging U.S. overdose deaths. The Washington Post. https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2026/01/08/fentanyl-death-decline-china-study/

fewer overdose deaths


Available data indicate that overdose deaths have declined, but this trend cannot be clearly attributed to border enforcement alone (Gallagher, 2025). The article cited in support of the claim notes that part of the reduction is associated with expanded access to medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD), which are intended to reduce overdose risk (Gallagher, 2025).


The Washington Post reports that final overdose death figures for 2025 have not yet been published (as of January 10, 2026) and should be reviewed once complete data become available (Ovalle & Cadell, 2026). Other reporting attributes some of the reduction in fentanyl availability to actions taken by China, including a multiagency crackdown following a 2023 meeting between President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping (Ovalle & Cadell, 2026). Notably, overdose deaths had already begun to decline before that agreement was reached.


In addition, some states and local governments have expanded the distribution of overdose prevention medications to the public, which may also contribute to lower fatality rates. Taken together, these factors suggest that the decline in overdose deaths is influenced by multiple interventions, making it difficult to link the trend directly to border enforcement efforts alone.


References:

Gallagher, A. (2025, December 9). Opioid Overdose Deaths Fall by 34% in 2025 | ASHP Midyear 2025. Drugtopics.com; Drug Topics. https://www.drugtopics.com/view/opioid-overdose-deaths-fall-by-34-in-2025-ashp-midyear-2025

Ovalle, D., & Cadell, C. (2026, January 8). A study offers a surprising reason for plunging U.S. overdose deaths. The Washington Post. https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2026/01/08/fentanyl-death-decline-china-study/

significant reductions


Some reports, including a Federalist article, note that certain hospitals in LA observed a reduction in emergency room visits and missed appointments among individuals identified as undocumented immigrants following increased immigration enforcement (Thies, 2025). However, these observations are localized and may reflect changes in behavior due to fear of enforcement rather than overall health trends. The data do not provide a nationwide picture, do not clearly define how immigration status was verified, and do not quantify the effect in a way that allows independent verification.


Emergency room usage is influenced by many factors, including access to primary care, public health programs, and socioeconomic conditions. Therefore, while some facilities may see changes in visits, there is no clear evidence that immigration enforcement has led to a significant reduction in emergency room use nationwide.


The word 'report' was hyperliked to the article on the Federalist


References:

Thies, B. F. (2025, July 22). ICE Is Helping Alleviate Pressure On America‚Äôs Emergency Rooms. The Federalist. https://thefederalist.com/2025/07/22/ice-is-helping-alleviate-pressure-on-americas-emergency-rooms/

"very" serious issue fell by nearly 15%


The statement that the share of Americans viewing crime as a "very" serious issue fell by nearly 15% in 2025 is potentially misleading (Rego, 2025). Public perception of crime does not directly measure actual crime rates, and attributing changes in perception to a single policy is speculative. In addition, focusing only on the category "'very' serious" selectively highlights part of the data while overlooking broader context.


Gallup survey data show that perceptions of crime severity have shifted over multiple years. From 2024 to 2025, the percentage of Americans who believed there was more crime in the U.S. declined by approximately 15% (Brenan, 2025). However, the share of respondents who described crime as extremely or very serious dropped 2 years in a row (2024 with 11.11% decrease and 2025 with 12.5% decrease) (Brenan, 2024; Brenan, 2025).


In 2025, 17% of adults described crime as "extremely" serious and 32% as "very" serious, compared with 25% and 31% in 2024 (Brenan, 2024; Brenan, 2025). This indicates that overall concern about crime shifted in nuanced ways rather than declining uniformly. As a result, claims that frame these perception changes as clear evidence of policy success oversimplify the data. This interpretation appears to stem from a mischaracterization of Gallup polling reported by The Hill, rather than from the underlying survey results themselves. (There was a 15% overall decrease, but specifying the word "very" is where the dissonance arises) (Rego, 2025).


References:

Brenan, M. (2024, October 29). Smaller Majorities Say Crime In U.S. Is Serious, Increasing. Gallup.com; Gallup. https://news.gallup.com/poll/652763/smaller-majorities-say-crime-serious-increasing.aspx

Brenan, M. (2025, October 30). Crime in U.S. Seen as Less Serious for Second Straight Year. Gallup.com; Gallup. https://news.gallup.com/poll/697124/crime-seen-less-serious-second-straight-year.aspx

Rego, M. (2025, October 30). Fewer Americans see crime as a serious problem: Poll. The Hill. https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/5581062-americans-crime-concerns-decline-gallup-poll/

killed, raped, and assaulted


The phrase uses dramatic language that implies a direct causal link between immigration enforcement and reductions in violent crime. Such wording goes beyond what can be supported by available evidence because it attributes specific outcomes (e.g., prevention of homicide, sexual assault, or other violence) directly to immigration policy. To establish causality, one would need rigorous, peer-reviewed data showing that these policies independently and significantly reduced violent crime rates, after controlling for other factors such as local policing strategies, economic conditions, demographic changes, and broader crime trends.


While there is evidence showing that some deported individuals had criminal convictions (DHS, 2025), and while some jurisdictions have reported declines in certain types of crime, these associations do not, on their own, demonstrate that immigration enforcement was the direct or primary cause of reductions in homicides, sexual assaults, or other violent offenses among American citizens. Statements that frame enforcement as definitively "saving lives" therefore overstate what the data currently show and should be supported by specific, transparent evidence linking policy actions to measured outcomes.


References:

Department of Homeland Security. (2025). ICE Arrests Worst of Worst Criminal Illegal Aliens Including Pedophiles, Rapists and Violent Assailants | Homeland Security. U.S. Department of Homeland Security. https://www.dhs.gov/news/2025/12/17/ice-arrests-worst-worst-criminal-illegal-aliens-including-pedophiles-rapists-and#:~:text=‚ÄúICE%20law%20enforcement,just%20the%20beginning.‚Äù

criminal illegal aliens with no right to be here


Undocumented immigrants, whether they hold a criminal conviction or not, have five rights given from our Constitution and laws. The rights do not include the "right to be here," but they include:


  1. The Right to Due Process (not guaranteed a hearing)
  2. The Right to Legal Counsel (in felony cases)
  3. The Right to be with Family
  4. The Right against Unreasonable Searches and Seizures (save for a "border search" exception)
  5. The Right to Education (for undocumented children) (Clearwater Law Group, 2025; Frazee, 2018)

Clearwater Law Group. (n.d.). 5 Rights of Undocumented Immigrants | Clearwater Law Group. Https://Clearwaterlawgrouptricities.com/. https://clearwaterlawgrouptricities.com/5-rights-of-undocumented-immigrants/

disturbing priorities


Describing opponents as having "disturbing priorities" reflects opinion rather than fact. It assumes intent and values without evidence and shifts the focus away from a discussion of specific policies or outcomes.

criminals ahead of Americans


The phrasing presents a false dichotomy that frames policy disagreement as a choice between public safety and national interest. It assumes that opposing viewpoints prioritize criminals over citizens without providing evidence for that claim. This framing oversimplifies complex policy debates and relies on rhetorical contrast rather than factual analysis of policy outcomes or intentions.


The word 'criminal' had a hyperlink to a post on X from AliBradleyTV:

The DHS article mentioned provides numbers, but does not cite underlying data sources. Increases described in the article may also be influenced by factors such as a higher number of ICE agents and more frequent or concentrated deployments in certain states. Additionally, the article uses emotionally charged language and appears to advocate for a particular response rather than offering neutral analysis (it would benefit from a more detailed, separate examination) (DHS, 2025).
